> Finding the modulus of a complex number

Find the modulus of the complex number \(\displaystyle z = \frac{{@num@}}{{@den@}}\)

Note: Give your answers in exact form i.e using fractions or writing in square root form

Worked Solution

To find the modulus of a complex number, you can use the formula:

\(|z| = \sqrt{{\text{Re}(z)}^2 + {\text{Im}(z)}^2}\),

where \(\text{Re}(z)\) is the real part of the complex number and \(\text{Im}(z)\) is the imaginary part.

Given the complex number \(\displaystyle z = \frac{{@num@}}{{@den@}}\), let's simplify it first:

\(\displaystyle z = \frac{{@num@}}{{@den@}}\)

To get rid of the denominator, you can multiply both the numerator and the denominator by \({@den_conj@}\):

\(\displaystyle z = \left( \frac{{@num@}}{{@den@}} \right) \left( \frac{{@den_conj@}}{{@den_conj@}} \right) \)

\(\displaystyle z = \frac{{@expand(num1)@}}{{@den1@}}\)

\(\displaystyle z = {@expand(z_conjugate)@}\)

Now we have the real and imaginary parts of the complex number:

\( \displaystyle \text{Re}(z) = {@re_z@}\)

\(\displaystyle \text{Im}(z) = {@im_z@}\)

Now we can plug these values into the modulus formula:

\(\displaystyle \left | z \right |= \sqrt{( {@re_z@})^2 + \left({@im_z@}\right)^2}\)

\(\displaystyle \left | z \right | = \sqrt{ {@re_z^2@} + {@im_z^2@}}\)

\(\displaystyle |z| = \sqrt{ {@re_z^2 + im_z^2@}}\)

\(\displaystyle |z| = {@mod@}\)

So, the modulus of the complex number \(\displaystyle z = \ \frac{{@num@}}{{@den@}}\) is \( \displaystyle {@mod@}\).
